title: How can one be good with probability? - Quora

response.answer_text: Start solving problems. I’m not sure where you’re at, but Grinstead and Snell’s book Introduction to Probability is the best book I’ve found on the subject. It’s got plenty of practice problems for you to work through. And how lucky for you that there’s a copy online: https://www.math.dartmouth.edu/~prob/prob/prob.pdf It has some statistics in it and so as a whole it is a good start. If you’re less of a textbook learner, then I suggest you watch through videos on Khan Academy or sign up to Brilliant and start working through problems there. I also can not help but mention Mosteller’s book Fifty Challenging Problems in Probability with Solutions. You could work through each problem learning new concepts as you go. Good luck.

Hey you. This is my answer to your question. Practice, practice, practice. Read, read, read. Ask, ask, ask. And ask statisticians to share with you on how they think (especially their critical thinking processes) in tackling situations or problems. I understand your question; and whilst I was a student (I do still think of myself as a student now and always); I would read the thick textbooks cover to cover, again and again until I felt and thought that I could understand and was able to comprehend what the fuck I was reading. I have to thank all my professors//lecturers for all the grueling hard times though; my professors used to produce questions that were harder than the standard SOA papers— just to mock us. :D but the questions (that made me cry in the examination halls because I felt so, so defeated— reading the textbooks again and again and practicing again and again and/or until I felt and thought I was ready for the exams but reading the questions in the examination hall just proved to me that I wasn’t at all ready) prepared and improved me for applying and solving shit.

Many will answer with academic resources which are great. In addition play board games that involve dice. I recommend backgammon, but think to yourself, what is the probability I get a 6 (either on 1 or 2 dice (this includes double 2’s. As the situation changes be aware of what rolls are beneficial and what rolls are detrimental to your position.

Practice more. If you feel you have started understanding problem after practice give everything to solve it. Few problems will be difficult to solve. Once you cracked that single problem you will start mastering it. However these problems will really test your patience and be ready to give even days or more to that problem at beginning. One such problem will be worth solving 20–30 simple problems.

Understand the way of approach to solve different problems and trying to solve them on your own only makes you good with probability. Understanding Permutations and combinations geometry also required because majority of probability problems have those concepts. Develop thinking and your own way of solving problems.

Probability should be applied in day to day problems, it's the best way to improve in it.. Further solve problems given in probabilities from some math books ,as they are examined thoroughly and that's enough for anyone to be a mediocre on the topic.
